isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9200, 9300, 9400 Models Built After January 1, 1995 - ELECTRICAL TROUBLESHOOTING CATERPILLAR 3176B AND 3406E ELECTRONIC ENGINES

svcsection.title: ELECTRICAL TROUBLESHOOTING CATERPILLAR 3176B AND 3406E ELECTRONIC ENGINES

lev1.para: This section covers International installed components and circuits that directly interact with the Caterpillar 3176B and 3406E engines.
The Caterpillar Electronic Troubleshooting Guide should be used to diagnose the engine control system.

This section does not provideengine diagnostics, but does provide step-by-step troubleshooting charts for International installed components and circuits. The charts in this section should be used when the Caterpillar Electronic Troubleshooting Guide indicates a problem may be present in a International circuit or component.

para.emph: Only systems that include International installed components and/or circuits are discussed in this section.

lev1.para: Refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Service Literature for additional information.
Caterpillar, Inc. Literature Orders Section P.O. Box 5319 Morton, IL 61550

lev1.title: OVERVIEW
lev1.para: The 3176B/3406E controllers provide engine and vehicle functions including:

lev2.title: Programmable Parameters
lev2.para: Certain programmable parameters that affect the engine electronic control systems may be changed with electronic service tools.

The parameters are stored in the system Electronic Control Module (ECM) and are protected from unauthorized change by passwords. The programmable parameters are either "System Parameters" or "Customer Parameters."

System Configuration Parametersare set at the factory and affect emissions or horsepower ratings within a family of engines. Factory passwords must be obtained and used to change System Configuration Parameters.

Customer Selectable Parametersare variable, and are used to specify operating parameters for: cruise control, PTO operation, vehicle speed limits, progressive shifting, type of engine protection system, RPM and horsepower ratings within the engine family. Customer passwords are needed to change Customer Parameters.
Since each 3176B/3406E control system is electronically programmable to individual owner specifications, the operating parameters will vary from vehicle to vehicle.

Some of these parameters may cause the engine to operate in a way that the driver (or service technician) does not expect, if proper training has not taken place. This may lead to power or performance complaints and/or service time, when the engine is operating correctly.
EXAMPLE:If the driver attempts to drive 60 mph and the vehicle speed limiting option has been programmed to limit vehicle speed to 55 mph, the driver may complain of low power.

lev2.title: Passwords
lev2.para: "System Configuration Parameters" are protected by Caterpillar factory passwords. Factory passwords are necessary to:

item.para: Program a new ECM. When an ECM is replaced, the System Configuration Parameters must be programmed into the new ECM. These parameters are protected by Factory Passwords.
Rerate engine to another engine family. This requires changing the Personality Module Code, which is protected by Factory Passwords.

Read Customer Passwords. If the owner loses the customer password, customer parameters cannot be changed. Using Factory Passwords, the customer passwords can be read, which can then be used to change customer parameters.
Clear certain logged Diagnostic Codes. Engine Overspeed and Incorrect Engine Software fault codes can only be cleared using Factory Passwords.

Factory passwords are only available to authorized Caterpillar dealers.Whenever a system configuration parameter is changed, insure that all appropriate components (suspension, drivelines, etc.) are matched with the new change. This may adversely affect warranty coverage.

note.para: For complete information on passwords, refer to the Caterpillar Electronic Troubleshooting Guide.

lev2.title: Self-Diagnostics
lev2.para: Caterpillar Electronic Engine Control systems have some ability to diagnose their own circuits. The ECM communicates with the Driver using a Yellow Serv/Check Engine and Red Engine Warning Light.

lev3.title: Yellow Oil/Water Warning Light
lev3.para: Caterpillar service literature refers to this light as the "Check Engine Light." This light is used for two purposes. The light is used to notify the driver that an active code has been logged or with the Idle Shutdown feature, the light flashes to indicate that the shutdown timer is within 90 seconds of shutting the engine down.
On power up (key ON and engine OFF), the Yellow Serv/Check Engine will come ON for five seconds and turn OFF, indicating that the bulb circuit is working properly.

When a problem condition is detected, an active diagnostic code is logged, which will cause the Yellow Serv/Check Engine to turn ON for five seconds, then flash OFF, then back ON for five seconds. It will repeat this until the condition is gone.
The code is also logged (stored) in the ECM permanent memory. This memory is not lost when turning the vehicle OFF or when disconnecting the batteries for a short period of time.

lev3.title: Active and Inactive Codes
lev3.para: Codes representing current conditions are called ACTIVEcodes. They indicate that a problem of some type currently exists. They should always be serviced.

If a fault condition occurred and caused a code to be logged, but is no longer present, the code is referred to as an INACTIVEcode. This can occur with an intermittent condition or when repairs are made and the code is not cleared. Logged inactive codes don't always mean something requires service. Some codes record events and not faults.

Codes caused by intermittent conditions are automatically cleared, if after 100 hours of ECM operation, the condition does not occur again. Codes that require a Factory Password to clear do not automatically clear.
With Engine Protection selected, the Red Engine Warning lightwill be activated.

lev2.title: Electronic Service Tools
lev2.para: Electronic service tools are designed to help the service technician locate faults and/or analyze problems within the 3176B/3406E systems. Diagnostic code reading and switch monitoring can be done using the service tools. An electronic service tool is necessary to read or change operating parameters.

lev3.title: Diagnostic Connector (137)
lev3.para: International provides a Diagnostic connector (137) for connecting an Electronic Service Tool (EST) to the electronic engine control system. The Diagnostic connector is located on the instrument panel left.

lev3.title: Caterpillar Service Tools
lev3.para: Caterpillar service tools are available for 3176B/3406E engines. The Electronic Control Analyzer Programmer (ECAP) and the Digital Diagnostic Tool (DDT) both can communicate with 3176B/3406E engines. Refer to Caterpillar Service Manual for complete information needed to use these tools.

lev3.title: MPSI Pro-Link 9000
lev3.para: The MPSI Pro-Link 9000 Electronic Service Tool is available with a single cartridge that communicates with both the Caterpillar 3176B/3406E engines. The Pro-Link 9000 communicates with the engine ECM through the Diagnostic connector. A manual is provided with the MPSI Caterpillar cartridge explaining its use.

This section does not discuss engine diagnostics, except as they relate to International installed circuits or components. Refer to the Caterpillar Engine Operators Manual furnished with the vehicle and/or other Caterpillar Electronic Troubleshooting Manuals for additional engine related information.

note.para: When referring to an electronic service tool (EST), this manual will make reference to the MPSI Pro-Link.

lev1.title: ELECTRICAL OPERATION
lev1.para: This section describes specific electrical operation of International installed circuits and components, referencing specific circuits, connectors and components by number.
Refer to circuit diagram CATERPILLAR 3176B/3406E - ENGINE CONTROLS in CTS-5119S.

lev2.title: Electronic Control Module (ECM)
lev2.para: The "Brain" of the 3176B/3406E Electronic Engine Control System is two components working together: the Electronic Control Module (ECM) and the Vehicle Personality Module (VPM). The ECM is mounted on the left side of the engine and the VPM is mounted on the ECM. The ECM is the computer which controls the engine related vehicle functions. The VPM contains the operating instructions (software) including owner selected parameters and other engine information for the ECM to use, controlling how the ECM behaves.

The International engine harness connector (400) connects to Caterpillar 40-pin connector J1. All electronic communication between the International electrical system and the Caterpillar engine control system go through (400)/J1, the International/Caterpillar connection.

lev3.title: Switched Power To The ECM
lev3.para: With the key switch ON, the ECM receives (12 volt DC) operating power from the vehicle batteries through International engine harness connector (400), terminal 6. The battery power to the ECM is switched ON or OFF by the Run Relay (144), which is energized when the key switch is in the IGN position.

item.para: Turning the key switch ON applies power from Ignition Adapter (494) to the control coil of the Run Relay (144), causing it to energize. The relay control coil circuit 13-GZ/11GT goes to ground through (506) Panel Light Ground Adapter.

Battery power from connector (497) B1 Battery Adapter is applied to Run Relay terminal 30. This circuit is protected by 20A fuse F9-B. With the relay energized, battery passes through the Normally Open (N.O.) relay contacts (87 to 30) and is sent on circuit 97S to International ECM connector (400) terminal 6.

lev3.title: Unswitched Battery Power To ECM
lev3.para: Battery power from the B+ BATTERY terminal of the Cranking Motor Solenoid is always applied on circuit 2FL/97F through connector (400) terminal 4 to the ECM. This circuit is protected by a fusible link 2FL.

The ECM uses this power to maintain a portion of memory used for customer trip data accumulators. Disconnecting this circuit does not affect engine operation or factory/customer parameters or logged diagnostic codes. Refer to the Caterpillar Electronic Troubleshooting manual for additional information on this feature.

lev3.title: ECM Inputs And Outputs
lev3.para: The ECM acts as 5V power supply for many Caterpillar and International components used to monitor and control the engine/vehicle systems. The ECM also supplies operating power to the Throttle Position Sensor (404), Low Coolant Sensor (402) and the Engine Fan Relay (410).
The ECM is connected to the International installed switches that communicate with the ECM. The switches are 2-way or 3-way switches and are either ON or OFF.
EXAMPLE OF A 2-WAY SWITCH:Cruise Control ON-OFF Switch (435)

The ECM needs to know if the Cruise ON/OFF switch is in the ON or OFF position. To accomplish this, the Cruise ON/OFF switch is connected to the ECM with input circuit 97AE and "common" or ground circuit 97-GH.

item.para: Each International installed switch has an "input" circuit that is connected through connector (400) to an assigned ECM terminal. This circuit has 5 volts applied at the ECM terminal.
Each switch is also grounded through connector (400) terminal 29 to the ECM. ECM terminal 5 is grounded at the engine ground stud by circuit 97-GB.

When the Cruise switch is OFF (switch open), the ECM sees 5 volts at ECM terminal 20. Placing the cruise switch to the ON position (switch closed) causes the ECM to see 0 volts (ground voltage will be 0 to 0.5 volts) at terminal 20. The ECM programming has established that the Cruise Control Switch is OFF when it sees 5 volts at connector (400) terminal 20 or cruise is ON when the ECM sees 0 volts at terminal 20.

lev3.para: EXAMPLE: The service brake switch (141) is connected by input circuit 97AL to connector (400) terminal 14. Terminal 14 has a 5-volt signal present. With the brake switch closed (pedal released), the circuit is complete between terminals 14 (input) and 29 (common or ground). This causes the 5 volt signal at terminal 14 to go to zero. This tells the ECM that the service brake switch is closed (pedal released).

This type of circuit is used to communicate switch and some sensor information to the ECM. Some sensors receive a 5 volt signal and return a variable voltage indicating some variable attribute. The ECM also uses 12 volt circuits to enable (energize) relays in the system and supplies 8V powerto operate the Throttle Position Sensor.
The ECM receives "inputs" through International connector (400) from the following International components:
The ECM receives the AC signal from the Vehicle Speed Sensor and sends a signal to the vehicle speedometer. The ECM also sends the signal to drive the vehicle tachometer.

lev2.title: Engine Protection
lev2.para: The 3176B/3406E engine control system includes an Engine Monitoring feature. This feature monitors:
*Installed by Caterpillar
**Installed by International.
The ECM can be programmed to four different customer selectable modes of engine monitoring:
Selecting any level except OFF activates the Red Engine Warning Light.

OFF MODE -The engine monitoring system can be turned OFF. If the customer selects this option, the Red Engine Warning light is not functional (except for reading codes), although the Yellow Serv/Check Engine will indicate if active fault conditions are present. If Engine Monitoring is turned OFF, the diagnostic codes for the following conditions are not enabled.

item.para: Coolant Level Sensor Fault (no sensor is installed)

lev2.para: Warning Only Mode(Default) - If the system is programmed for Warning Only mode, the ECM will indicate the diagnostic codes for conditions listed in the Code Description Table - Warning Only, that are active, using the Yellow Oil/Water Warning Light. The ECM will also turn ON the Red Engine Warning Light when the necessary conditions exist. This is the engine protection mode programmed if no other option is selected when ordering the vehicle.

entry.para: High Intake Manifold Air Temp. Warning
Very High Intake Manifold Air Temp. Warning

lev2.para: Derate Mode- If the system is programmed for the Derate mode, the ECM will indicate that diagnostic codes for the conditions listed in Code Description Table - Derate Mode, that are active using the Yellow Serv/Check Engine and also turn ON the Red Engine Warning Light when the necessary conditions exist.

item.para: Conditions causing active codes for Low Oil Pressure Warningand Low Coolant Level Warningwill cause the Red Engine Warning light to come on solid (light stays ON).

Conditions causing active codes for High Coolant Temperatureor Very High Coolant Temperatureor Very Low Oil Pressurewill cause the Red Engine Warning Light to flash. The Red Engine Warning Light will FLASH whenever engine power is derated.When derated, the available engine power and vehicle speed will be limited (if due to Very Low Oil Pressure, engine RPM is also limited).

entry.para: High Intake Manifold Air Temp. Warning
Very High Intake Manifold Air Temp. Warning

lev2.para: Shutdown Mode- If the system is programmed to Shutdown mode, the ECM will indicate that diagnostic codes for the conditions listed in Code Description Table - Shutdown Mode, that are active using the Yellow Oil/Water Warning Light.

item.para: Conditions causing active codes for Low Oil Pressure Warningor Low Coolant Level Warningwill cause the Red Engine Warning Light to come on solid (doesn't flash).

Conditions causing active codes for High Coolant Temperatureor Very High Coolant Temperatureor Very Low Oil Pressureor Very Low Coolant Levelwill cause the Red Engine Warning Light to flash (indicating derate).
If conditions causing active codes for Very High Coolant Temperatureor Very Low Oil Pressureor Very Low Coolant Levelcontinue to be present after derate, the engine will shut down.

entry.para: High Intake Manifold Air Temp. Warning
Very High Intake Manifold Air Temp. Warning

lev3.title: Yellow "Oil/Water" Warning Light
lev3.para: On power up (key ON - engine OFF), the Yellow Serv/Check Engine light will come ON for five seconds and then turn OFF indicating that the light circuit is working properly. Any time there are active codes logged, the lamp will come ON for five seconds, blink OFF, then turn ON for five more seconds. It will repeat this process until the condition causing the code is corrected.
The Engine Warning Light can be used to flash diagnostic codes so that the codes can be read without using an electronic service tool.

The Yellow Serv/Check Engine light receives power from 10A fuse F4-A when the key is ON. Circuit 97AZ connects the ground side of the light to ECM connector (400) terminal 27. The ECM opens or closes a ground switch turning the light ON or OFF in response to engine conditions.

lev3.title: Red Engine Warning Light
lev3.para:
The Red Engine Warning light is active unless the customer has selected the OFF level of Engine Protection.
If the OFF engine protection mode is selected, the Red Engine Warning light only is used to read flash codes. The purpose of this light is to alert the driver that an engine problem has been detected by the ECM, and that action may be taken by the ECM to protect the engine.
The Red Engine Warning light is ON continuously while in the Warning mode.
The Red Engine Warning light flashes while in the Derate mode. In this mode the light flashes to indicate that the ECM is reducing available engine speed, vehicle speed or horsepower.

At power up (key ON - engine OFF), the light comes ON for two seconds and then turns OFF to check the light bulb and circuit. If a low oil pressure condition is present at start up, the light will stay ON for 15 seconds, before the ECM will log a Low Oil Pressure Diagnostic code.

The Red Engine Warning light receives power from 10A fuse F4-A when the key is ON. Circuit 97AT connects the ground side of the light to ECM connector (400) terminal 22. The ECM opens or closes a ground switch for this circuit turning the light ON or OFF in response to engine conditions.

lev3.title: Engine Coolant Level Switch (402)
lev3.para: The Coolant Level Sensor is a fluid- level-actuated switch that sends coolant low or coolant high signal and provides a warning when coolant is being lost. It is mounted in the coolant surge tank.

It is an electronic switch that operates on the electrostatic or capacitance principle, and cannot be tested with a multimeter. The probe extends into the coolant and produces a change in capacitance when coolant displaces air immediately surrounding the probe. This change is converted in the switch to an ON/off solid state switch closure indicating the absence or presence of coolant. The switch is electrically insulated providing a slick, non-fouling surface as well as good electrical characteristics to prevent current flow into the coolant.
The Coolant Level switch connects to a 4-pin connector (402) on the International engine harness. All four Coolant Level Switch circuits go through the engine harness to connector (400).

item.para: Coolant Level Switch terminal (C) receives VREF (5V) on circuit 34B from the ECM connector (400) terminal 36.
Coolant Level Switch terminal (B) is grounded through circuits 34-G/97-G at ECM connector (400) terminal 29.

When the coolant level is NORMAL (above the probe), the ECM expects to see: a 5-volt signal (3.5V minimum) from sensor terminal D (circuit 34A) at connector (400) terminal 2 AND a 0-volt signal (0.7V maximum) from sensor terminal A (34) at connector (400) terminal 23.

When the coolant level is below the probe, the ECM expects to see: a 5-volt signal (3.5V minimum) from sensor terminal A (circuit 34) at connector (400), terminal 23 AND a 0-volt signal (0.7V maximum) from sensor terminal D (34A) at connector (400), terminal 2.

To prevent false signals from coolant sloshing, a several second delay is built into the logic. For example: to log a Coolant Low Fault, the LOW signal must be seen by the ECM for several continuous seconds before the code is logged.

lev3.title: Engine Oil Pressure Sensor (CAT Component)
lev3.para: The Caterpillar installed engine oil pressure sensor is part of the transducer module, located below the rack actuator housing on the left side of the engine. To diagnose the operation of this sensor, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Service Manual.

lev3.title: Engine Coolant Temperature Sensor (CAT Component)
lev3.para: The Caterpillar installed engine coolant temperature sensor is located in the water outlet housing. The engine sends a 5 volt signal to the sensor and a variable signal (0.5 to 5.5 volts) is returned to the ECM. To diagnose the operation of this sensor, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Service Manual.

lev2.title: ATA Data Link Connector (137)
lev2.para: The six-pin ATA Data Link connector (137) allows Electronic Service Tools (EST) to communicate with the ECM. The data link carries serial data transmissions between the ECM and the electronic service tool and provides vehicle and engine speed information to the speedometer/tachometer unit. The data link provides communication capabilities for:
Data Link connector (137) is located on left instrument panel. Four of the six connector cavities have terminals. Those terminals and connecting circuits are as follows:

item.para: Terminal A, circuit 98A(+) connects Data Link connector (137) to (514) Datalink Positive bus connector. Circuit 98(+) connects (514) Datalink Positive bus connector to ECM connector (400) terminal 7. Bus connector (514) is also connected by circuit 47/48(+) through connector (421) to the Speedometer and Tachometer unit. Note that bus connector (514) acts like a splice, electrically connecting all circuits into the connector together.

Terminal B, circuit 98C(-) connects Data Link connector (137) to (515) Datalink Negative bus connector. Circuit 98B(-) connects (515) Datalink Negative bus connector to ECM connector (400) terminal 1. Bus connector (515) is also connected by circuit 47/48(-) through connector (421) to the Speedometer/ Tachometer unit. Note that bus connector (515) acts like a splice, electrically connecting all circuits into the connector together.
The positive and negative data link circuits are twisted wire pairs (2 twists per inch, minimum). The twisting of the wires shields the wires from interference.

Terminal C, circuit 97DL supplies ignition voltage (12V) for electronic service tools, when the key is ON. Circuit 97DL receives power from the Run Relay (144). The circuit is protected by 5A fuse F9-C.
Terminal E, circuit 97-GR is grounded through circuit 11-GT at Panel Light Ground Adapter (506).

lev2.title: Cruise and PTO Controls
lev2.para: Refer to circuit diagram CATERPILLAR 3176B/3406E - CRUISE CONTROL in CTS-5119S.

The cruise control switches are used as PTO controls (if vehicle is so equipped) when the vehicle road speed is not present (this is an owner selected parameter). Refer to the Owner's Manual furnished with the vehicle for Cruise Control operating instructions.

lev3.title: Cruise ON/OFF Switch (435)
lev3.para: This is a lighted switch to allow for easy location in the dark. Cruise ON/OFF switch circuit (97AE) is an input to the ECM through connector (400) terminal 20. The ground side of the ON/OFF switch is connected through circuit 97-GH/97-GA/97-G to connector (400) terminal 29. With the switch ON, the ECM sees 0 volts at connector (400) terminal 20. With the switch OFF, the ECM sees 5 volts at connector (400) terminal 20.

lev3.title: Cruise Set/Resume Switch (436)
lev3.para: This is a lighted switch to allow for easy location in the dark. SET/RESUME switch terminal 2 is connected to the ECM through circuit 97-GD/97-GA/97-G to the connector (400) terminal 29. SET/RESUME switch SET terminal 3 is an input (circuit 97AB) to the ECM through connector (400) terminal 25. SET/RESUME switch RESUME terminal (1) is an input (circuit 97AA) to the ECM through connector (400) terminal 15.
With the SET/RESUME switch in the SET position, the ECM sees 0 volts at connector (400) terminal 25 and 5 volts at terminal 15.
In RESUME position, the ECM sees 5 volts at connector (400) terminal 25 and 0 volts at terminal 15.
In the SET/RESUME neutral position, the ECM sees 5 volts at both connector (400) terminals 15 and 25.

lev3.title: Service Brake Switch (141)
lev3.para: Service brake switch circuit 97AL is an input to the ECM through connector (400) terminal 14. The ground or common side of the Service Brake switch is connected through circuit 97-GB/97-GA/97-G to connector (400) terminal 29. With service brakes released(switch closed), the ECM sees 0 volts at connector (400) terminal 14. Applying the brakes opens the switch, and the ECM sees 5 volts at terminal 14.

lev3.title: Clutch Switch
lev3.para: The Clutch Switch is a normally open switch, that is adjusted to be closedwhile the clutch pedal is RELEASED.

The clutch switch connects to the cab harness at connector (294). Clutch switch circuit (97AH) is an input to the ECM through connector (400) terminal 24. The ground side of the clutch pedal switch is grounded through circuit 97-GE/97-GA/97-G to connector (400) terminal 29. With the driver's foot off the clutch pedal (switch closed), the ECM sees 0 volts at terminal 24. When the driver depresses the clutch pedal (switch opens), the ECM sees 5 volts at terminal 24.

lev3.title: Vehicle Speed Sensor (409)
lev3.para: The Vehicle Speed Sensor is located at the rear of the transmission. The sensor contains a permanent magnet that creates a magnetic field that is interrupted by the teeth on the speedometer output gear. As the rotating speedometer gear teeth repeatedly interrupt the sensor magnetic field, a variable AC voltage is generated and transmitted to the ECM. From sensor connector (409) circuits 97AJ and 97AK carry the signal to ECM connector (400) terminals 12 and 18.

lev2.title: Speedometer/Tachometer inputs
lev2.para: The input signal to the speedometer and tachometer with the 3176B and 3406E Caterpillar engines is provided by the ECM through the ATA data link circuits 98(+) and 98B(-) to Datalink Positive bus connector (514) and Datalink Negative bus connector (515), then circuit 47/48(+) from (514) and and 47/48(-) from (515) connect to the speedometer/tachometer unit at connector (421). Refer ATA Data Link Connectorfor discussion of data link circuits.

lev3.title: Speedometer/Tachometer Unit
lev3.para: Refer to Gauges And Warning Lights section in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.
The ECM receives and processes a signal from Engine Position sensor (Cummins component) to determine engine speedand receives a signal from the vehicle speed sensor to determine vehicle speed.
To calculate vehicle speed from the vehicle speed sensor signal, the ECM is programmed with certain vehicle parameters (refer to ECM Speedometer Programming, below.
The ECM provides a signal over the data link circuits that the vehicle speedometer and tachometer cluster microprocessor uses to drive the gauges.

lev3.title: Positive Data Link Circuit To Speedometer And Tachometer
lev3.para: Positive data link circuit 98(+) connects ECM connector (252) terminal 27 to Datalink Positive Connector (514) at terminal B. Datalink Positive Connector (514) terminal C is connected by circuit 47/48(+) to speedometer/tachometer connector (421). Datalink Positive Connector (514) terminal A is connected by circuit 98A(+) to the ATA Data Link connector (137) terminal A. Connector (514) has a bus installed that connects all the circuits in the connector together.ATA Data Link connector (137) can be used to access information on the data link using an electronic service tool.

lev3.title: Negative Data Link Circuit To Speedometer And Tachometer
lev3.para: Negative data link circuit 98B(-) connects ECM connector (252) terminal 8 to Datalink Negative Connector (515) at terminal B. Datalink Negative Connector (515) terminal C is connected by circuit 47/48(-) to speedometer/tachometer connector (421). Datalink Negative Connector (515) terminal A is connected by circuit 98C(-) to the ATA Data Link connector (137) terminal B.

Connector (515) has a bus installed that connects all the circuits in the connector together. ATA Data Link connector (137) can be used to access information on the data link using an electronic service tool.

lev3.title: ECM Speedometer Programming
lev3.para: The ECM is programmed with vehicle component information, so that the signal from the ECM to the speedometer/ tachometer unit causes the unit to display correct readings.

If the vehicle tire size, axle ratio or number of teeth on the transmission speedometer gear are changed, the ECM will have to be reprogrammed with the new pulses per mile data.The speedometer/tachometer unit does not get reprogrammed. The Prolink EST or Caterpillar EST can be used for the reprogramming. Refer to Caterpillar or Prolink manual for this procedure.

lev3.title: Calculating Pulses Per Mile (PPM)
lev3.para: PPM= M x Ra x N

M = Tire revolutions per mile = 10085 divided by the tire radius. Also the following table Radial/Bias Tire Revolutions Per Mile Tablelists revolutions per mile for various size tires. The table information is an average from several tire manufacturers. Tire manufacturers can also provide specific information for their tires.
Ra = Rear axle ratio which can normally be found on the rear axle housing or on the lineset ticket. With a 2-speed axle use the high range ratio.
N = The number of teeth on the transmission speedometer output gear. International installed transmissions, including Allison, have 16 teeth on the speedometer output gear.
EXAMPLE: If a vehicle has 10 x 22 tires and 3.70:1 rear axle:

item.para: Refer to the table, the revolutions per mile (M) = 476.
The formula is PPM = M x Ra x N

lev3.para: The new pulses per mile then is programmed into the ECM using the Prolink EST. The Caterpillar ECM will accept a number between 1716 PPM and 65,535 PPM.

lev3.title: Tachometer Programming
lev3.para: The Caterpillar Engine Speed/Timing sensor signal to the ECM is used to determine engine speed (RPM). This information is transmitted over the data link circuits to the speedometer/tachometer connector (421). The speedometer/tachometer unit is programmed at the factory to operate on this type of signal.

table.title: Radial/Bias Tire Revolutions Per Mile Table

lev2.title: Throttle Position Sensor (404)
lev2.para: Refer to circuit diagram CATERPILLAR 3176B - CRUISE CONTROL in CTS-5119S.

The pedal mounted Throttle Position Sensor (TPS) is used to provide a throttle signal to the ECM. Sensor output is a constant frequency signal with a pulse width that varies with throttle position. This output signal is referred to as either "Duty Cycle" or a "Pulse Width Modulated" (PWM) signal and is expressed as a percentage between 0 and 100%.

The pedal mounted Throttle Position Sensor is attached directly to the throttle pedal assembly and requires no adjustment. This sensor can be replaced separately from the throttle pedal assembly, however an incorrectly calibrated pedal mounted throttle position sensor assembly cannot be calibrated- the pedal assembly must be replaced.
The "soda can" style remote sensor is not used by International on 1995 engines and is not discussed in this manual.

The TPS connects to the cab harness at three-pin connector (404). When the ECM is powered (key switch ON), the TPS receives operating voltage (8 volts)at terminal A on circuit 99E, which is connected to ECM connector (400) terminal 35. TPS terminal B is grounded by circuit 99-G/97-GA/97-G through ECM connector (400) terminal 29.
TPS terminal C outputs the variable throttle position signal on circuit 99 to ECM connector (400) terminal 37.

The pedal mounted TPS should produce a Duty Cycle of 10 to 22 percent at low idle and 75 to 90 percent at full throttle. An electronic service tool can be used to monitor the signal. The percent duty cycle is translated in the ECM into a throttle position percentage of 3 to 100%.

lev2.title: Engine Brake Controls
lev2.para: Refer to circuit diagram CATERPILLAR 3176B - ENGINE BRAKE in CTS-5119S.

This manual only discusses engine brake control circuits and components installed by International: the Engine Brake ON/OFF switch (434), the Engine Brake Selector switch (433) and the connecting circuits. The International installed Clutch Switch (294) and Service Brake Switch (141) also provide inputs to the Engine Brake Control System and are discussed in paragraphs 1.2.4.3 and 1.2.4.4 .
For a complete description of Engine Brake Operation, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Service Manual.
There are two owner selected Engine Brake operation modes, which are COAST and LATCH.

lev3.title: COAST Operation Mode
lev3.para: If the COAST mode (standard mode) is selected, the engine brake operates when:

item.para: The driver's foot is off the throttle pedal (throttle position less than 7%).
The Service Brake pedal is depressed (engine brake only operates while service brake is applied).
The cruise control switch can be in the ON position, although it will be disabled by applying the service brake.

lev3.title: LATCH Operation Mode
lev3.para: If the LATCH mode is selected, the engine brake operates when:

item.para: The driver's foot is off the throttle pedal (throttle position less than 7%).
The cruise control switch must be OFF.

The engine brake operates when the driver applies the service brake, but the engine brake continues to operate (LATCHES ON so to speak) after the driver takes his foot off the brake. The engine brake stays engaged (LATCHED ON) until one of the other ECM inputs changes: clutch pedal depressed, throttle pedal depressed, engine speed drops below 950 rpm or the brake pedal is depressed a second time.

lev3.title: Engine Brake Control
lev3.para: Control of the engine brake is shared by the driver and the ECM. The driver turns the engine brake ON or OFF and selects how much engine brake is desired (number of cylinders). The ECM monitors certain engine parameters, then enables the engine brake system when all conditions are acceptable.

lev3.title: Engine Brake With Antilock Brake System
lev3.para: When Antilock Brakes (ABS) are installed with an Engine Brake also installed, the ABS controller is connected to the ECM through J1922 connector (403). This connection allows the ABS controller to communicate with the ECM by serial data circuits 98Z(+) and 98Y(-). These circuits are a twisted wire pair. This allows the ECM to TURN OFF the engine brake when the ABS system detects that a vehicle wheel is encountering a slippery road surface.

lev3.title: ON/OFF Switch (434)
lev3.para: To enable (turn ON) the Engine Brake Control System, this switch must be ON (closed). With the ON/Off switch closed, the circuit between ECM connector (400) terminal 29 and the Engine Brake selector switch terminal 2 is complete.

lev3.title: Engine Brake Selector Switch (433)
lev3.para: The Engine Brake Selector Switch has three circuits, Low, Medium and a common or ground circuit connected to the engine brake ON/Off switch.

Selector switch terminal 2 is connected by circuit 24A to the Engine Brake ON/Off switch (434) at terminal 5. When the ON/Off switch is ON, the circuit between the engine brake selector switch (433) terminal 2 and ECM connector (400) terminal 29 is complete.
With the Selector switch (433) in the Low position, the ECM sees a 0 volt signal at connector (400) terminal 19 and a 5 volt signal at terminal 13.
With the Selector switch (433) in the Medium position, the ECM sees a 0 volt signal at connector (400) terminal 13 and a 5 volt signal at terminal 19.
With the Selector switch (433) in the High position, the ECM sees a 0 volt signal at connector (400) terminal 13 and 19.

lev2.title: Idle Shutdown Timer System
lev2.para: The idle shutdown timer is a feature which helps improve fuel consumption by limiting idle time. The "shutdown time" is a customer specified parameter, and may be from 3 to 60 minutes. Programming the time to zero shuts the timer OFF.
The timer is activated and the countdown (from the customer selected time) begins when:

item.para: The engine is not under load (with or without the park brake set).

lev2.para: Ninety seconds before the programmed time is reached, the Yellow Serv/Check Engine light will begin to flash rapidly. If the driver moves the clutch or service brake pedal during this 90-second time period, the timer will be overridden until it is reset. The timer is reset and begins counting over by moving the vehicle a short distance.

A code (Override of Idle Shutdown Timer) will be logged when the driver overrides the timer within the 90-second time period. If the timer is activated and allowed to shut down the engine, then a code (Idle Shutdown Timed Out) will be set. These codes record an event- they do not indicate a fault in the system.

important.para: Note that the system shuts the engine down, but does not turn off power to the vehicle.
